reviewText: It has been more than a year now...the devs have completely abandoned the game for the PS4 console version.  Trust me, this is not an exaggeration.  PC hasn't been patched in ages, while the console version recieves multiple upgrades with new maps, game modes, voice chat, etc.  That's right folks, the PC version doesn't have voice chat, and the console version does.  Just checkout the Loadout home page's news feed.  I spent several months playing this game and supporting it through microtransactions (cosmetics), and they completely ditched the PC fanbase.\n\nEdge of Reality is a disgrace.  They aren't even upfront about it, and instead put us off with fake promises.  Screw you guys!

reviewText:
This game ♥♥♥♥in' ROCKS, lemme tell ya why:

Pros:
+Fun multiplayer
+Fun weapon customising
+Easy to join up with friends
+Decent F2P model
+Weapon variety
+Map variety
+Fairly easy to get used to

Cons:
-Game balance is sometimes screwy
-Some weapon mods are clearly better than others
-It takes a lot of time to get weapon mods and levels

Sounds good, right? Well...

These next cons make the game ♥♥♥♥in' SUCK, lemme tell ya why:

-This game is abandoned
-The devs used the PC version as a beta for their PS4 version
-They even announced that they weren't gonna keep working on this
-They're shutting down servers, and they already have shut down servers in Australia, making it unplayable there
-If you don't have a PS4, good ♥♥♥♥in' luck playing this game

FINAL SCORE: 3/10

In short, this game was fun before the devs abandoned it. Now, they've left Steam in the dust, with basically a middle finger to anyone who invested time and money into their game. Thank God I didn't spend any money in this game.

reviewText:
Please enjoy some excerpts from the Loadout's Privacy Policy (still current as of September 2014):

When you are playing or otherwise using the Game, the Game may monitor your Device to learn about your gameplay behavior, player stats, and purchasing, as well as other information...The Game may also monitor your computer’s random access memory (RAM) and your Device...In addition to any personal information or other information that you choose to submit to us, we and our third-party service providers may use a variety of technologies such as cookies, pixel tags and web beacons, browser analysis tools, and web server logs. As you use our Loadout Applications, your browser and devices communicate with servers operated by us, our business partners and our Product and Service providers...We may also collect information about the website you were visiting before you came to our Loadout Applications and the website you visit after you leave our Loadout Applications...The information from cookies and related technology is stored in web server logs...Cookies allow us to recognize you when you return, track and target your interests... “Persistent” cookies are more permanent cookies that are stored on your computers or mobile devices even beyond when you exit your browser. We use persistent cookies for a number of purposes...

The above terms can be found on their website:  http://www.loadout.com/privacy-policy/

The list of these offenses goes on and on! If you don't mind a company knowing and selling everything about you, then accept this agreement and create an account. As for me and the other concerned people on Steam: NO WAY!


What's even more concerning is the fact that I declined the Privacy Policy (which is displayed only after you enter all your private information), but out of curiosity, I jumped back into the game to see if it saved my e-mail, username, password, etc. and IT DID!
I DO NOT, AND DID NOT, GIVE CONSENT TO THIS COMPANY RETAINING OR USING MY PERSONAL INFORMATION with such a terrible Privacy Policy!


*****UPDATES*****

May 1, 2014 -- I just received one of their mass distribution/list e-mails from them today (announcing the new 3.0 update)! So, even though I DID NOT Consent to their privacy policy or finalize my account creation with them, they STILL recorded and utilized my private information for advertising.
There is something wrong with this companies data usage if they can't even differentiate between data they collected/stored erroneously (which should have been destroyed when one of the parties did not agree to the contract), and those persons of whom they actively store, sell, and track details.

June 6, 2014 - I'm still on this company's e-mail list!?! I just received an e-mail update announcing 4.0...Why are they still using my e-mail?!?
June 7, 2014 - Yet another e-mail sent to me about this game coming to the PS4. I wish someone had warned me about this company's spam and advertising policy before all of this.
June 20, 2014 - Another e-mail about their Summer Sale stuff. Please stop!


FINAL UPDATE:  I did block the e-mails since the unsubscribe never seemed to work for me. I do not appreciate the constant nasty comments personally attacking me and cursing me for disagreeing with this company's Privacy Policy. I might respond in the comments, but don't expect me to...I don't play the game, and you can take the review for what it's worth, meaning focused on the Privacy Policy.
Lastly, I get a lot of people commenting that Steam does this the exact same thing as this developer. Please read the Steam Privacy Policy here:
http://store.steampowered.com/privacy_agreement/
The only few items related are pixel tagging for account security (to prevent theft of your account authorization). You will not see any RAM monitoring/capturing, monitoring web browsing activity, or sharing of your personal information with third parties. As for comparing Loadout's Privacy Policy with companies like Google...come on. You can choose what sites you want to visit, the same way I can choose not to use Google, or play this game with it's terrible Privacy Policy. Please think people.

reviewText: It's sad to say, but after years of playing this game (and around 350 hours of my life), I have to leave Loadout a negative review. The reason for this is simple - the devs have given up on the PC version of this game in favor of the cash-grab that is the PS4 version. Forgetting their roots, the Loadout team has cut ties with the PC world in a real way - they've outright admitted that they are not planning on supporting the PC version of this game any longer. This means that all the problems which are present - unbalanced weapon builds, buggy game types (jackhammer, I'm looking at you), tiny map variety, and unfinished game dynamics - are never going to be improved upon.\n\nAfter a lot of thought, I played my last Loadout match today. This game used to be great - one of my favorites - but the team that made it great has decided to cut off its head. Oh well, onto the next game, I suppose.

reviewText:
Okay. I just want to clear things up here.
Yes, I have over 400 hours invested in this game.
Yes, this game is enjoyable with friends.
Yes, I'm pretty active on the Loadout forums.

But the thing is, the only thing that is keeping me somewhat associated with Loadout is the community and art, everything else is boring and unorganised.

Let's start with the main part of the game, the weaponcrafting.
Weaponcrafting is an interesting concept. It gives you HEAPS of customization options for your weapons and that's a good thing... right? Wrong. Half of these weapon parts are either useless or just worse than their counterparts. The other half is used by 90% of the entire playerbase. What's the point of being creative in this game when you just get killed by two hit rockets that are being held by someone who might as well be eating popcorn while he watches the fireworks. Once you get used to the SUPER WACKY CUSTOMIZATION!" the game becomes bland and boring because you're constantly seeing the same thing over and over again. Shield users

reviewText:
NOTE: The steam counter for how many hours I've played is not accurate.

Loadout was one of my favorite multiplayer shooters I have ever played. I only spent a few hours on steam, but I've spent more than 50 hours on the ps4 version. I decided to jump back into the PC version and now I have a verdict on this version.

Loadout is a very unique F2P shooter. You have the ability to create different combinations of weapons and use them to blow up or dismember your opponents. You have a lot of options and every combination is fun to create and fun to use in  combat.

The game also had a very smart approach to Free to play. The game allowed you to use the money for gun parts which didn't make the gun over powered.

The player base is currently still alive and kicking and you can jump into any game mode without any trouble.

All the game modes are incredibly fun, so if you get sick of one game mode you can quickly jump into another without a problem.

You might be asking yourself, why I'm giving this game a negative review then if all the things that I listed make the game seem awesome. Well the reality is the PC version is terrible compared to the PS4 version.

The game has been abandoned by the developers, who announced that the servers will shutdown and not to mention no updates for a while now.

Some connection issues also ruin the fun of the game, but that rarely happens so I doubt you will run into that problem.

In the end this game is incredibly fun, but the devs abandoned the game, so there is next to no reason to play the PC version. If you have a PS4 that is the place to play the superior version of the game.

Final Rating:
4/10 - Don't bother with the PC version

If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you dislike post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
tl;dr: The game was abandoned. You may still play it but don't spend any cash on it.

I bought Steam Launch Starter Pack in June 2014. I played the game a bit and I loved it but I removed it shortly after that. So a few days ago I decided to give it a try again. I bought Blutes and XP boosts and I tried to play the game again. I thought people still play Loadout. Boy, was I wrong.

Turns out the game was almost completely abandoned. It used to have about 30 000 people playing it at the same time, now this number is closer to 500. I have a feeling most of them randomly found Loadout on Steam Store, saw it's free and decided to play it a bit. Casual matchmaking is still possible — just select European or American servers depending on time of a day.

Moreover the game was abandoned by its developers. It used to get updates almost every week. Now they won't even add PvE mode (PS4 received it almost right after launch in January 2015). After PS4 launch Loadout's creative director left the development team. Shortly after that 12 people working on Loadout were fired and the game does not receive any more content.

So don't do the same mistake as I did: do not invest money in this game, it's dead. Feel free to try it. It's sad actually, the game itself is pretty decent. I have a feeling Edge of Reality is going to keep servers running until they can cover expenses. They already shut down Australian servers.

reviewText:
All of my experience on this game is with at least one other person I know, I note this to ensure a review that's fair by playing the game the way I imagine it was meant to be experienced.

To cut it short for those who don't want to read; the game is mainly ruined by its community. I waited all these hours before making this review just to make sure I didn't make a mistake.

I originally started playing this game due to wanting a game other than Counter-strike to play with my colleagues at work. This turned out to be a very good choice due to how well it runs on my work computer. It is an i3 with Intel HD4000, quite low specs compared to the majority of PCs today.

I'll start with praising how well optimized this game appears to be; I get about 45 fps solid on lowest settings, and it looks great. I have experienced it on my home computer, and the graphics are of course, even more impressive; but that's not where I choose to play this game.

The game has a cool concept; build your own gun and fight in teams in various game modes. When you first play it, you'll get a very TF2-style vibe from it. It's fast paced and cartoony.

The first problem arises in the perspective of third person. This isn't a heavy criticism, because the developers are trying something a bit different here; setting third person in a fast paced environment. In games like this, I like to be able to look around a lot, checking my back, and it gets a bit annoying with the camera behind you. This is just my personal criticism, so I'm sure some people like it this way.

There is something incredibly off-feeling about the aiming in the game, someone I know also noted this. I'm experienced in playing shooters, and I cannot at all get the hang of this, after 70 hours. There is some weird depth-perception issue for me, where I will often shoot the ground in front of myself, instead of an enemy further back. I can't put my finger on this, but I'm going to note it in the review (and yes, I have increased the FOV).

Next, the servers and client issues. There is a lot of client-side control in this game, it seems. You will often die, but still manage to kill someone after it's stated you are dead; simply due to lag. You might not see yourself die for a few seconds, giving you chance to shoot at people before it updates. With the gamemode 'Jackhammer', the hammer carriers will very often kill each other at the same time. Some might say it adds more fun into the game, but I find it mildly fustrating and in general it just looks buggy.

Now, the main gripe. The community. To put it simply, the community is not what you expect. It's not friendly like TF2, nor is it as awful as counter-strike. It's worse. You will get a lot of arguing in the chat between players, and constantly spammed with 'ez', regardless of the state of the game. But that's not really it.

It's the amount of cheaters that infest this game. The game developers, as far as I can tell, haven't put a lot of effort into countering cheaters. There is a report function, but I have no idea if that actually works, of course. Some cheaters are more obvious that others, but due to the way the community is, you'll often bump into these people the next day, and the next day, and so fourth, as I've experienced. Now, these players do get banned, eventually; but the fact it goes on for so long is pretty terrible.

One factor I've also noticed regarding gameplay is the unbalance of the weapons. I say unbalance, because I have been unsuccessful in reaching the damage other players have with very similar guns. I've had people with standard-looking pulse guns that kill you in three hits, without reduction in firing speed. Now, this could be part of the cheating fiasco, simply aimbots shooting the head for extra damage, but it's not really possible to tell.

I hesitated for a long time for atleast 30 hours of gameplay, deciding on whether to recommend this game or not. It's a cool game, but in the end, the community just makes it not worth it. I also don't really like the boasting-emotes the developers put out there, just adds to the doucheyness experienced.

reviewText:
Before I delve too deeply into this review, I first want to say that I don't recommend this game because of the quality, but because of the lacking updates, the cash shop prices, and the current population of the game.

The goodThis is a grand embodiment of your typical fast paced arena shooter. The gameplay encourages both high amounts of verticality and versitility. If games like Doom, Quake, or Unreal Tournament strike your fancy, then this is for you. The real cream of the game rests in the weapon crafting system, where you can craft virtually any weapon that suits your playstyle.

The badThe game doesn't seem like it's being updated very frequently. I first staretd playing Loadout about a year ago. The amount of content that's been released during that time has been lacking to say the least. No new weapons have been added from the default Ball, Rifle, Laser, and Rocket types. Very very few attachments have been added. There are a couple new levels, and a couple reskinned levels that have been added. No new characters, and very very little has been added to the cosmetic shop. The population of the game is arguably dwindling. It's not uncommon to be paired off against the same player time and time again throughout the course of a few hours of gaming.

The cost of cash shop items are atrocious and is not very wallet friendly. Currently, 600 spacebux costs $1, and 16000 costs $20. It costs 2000 spacebux to buy 1 gunslot, and 6000 spacebux for 1 loadout. The amount of gunslots you get as a player isn't half bad, since they give you 9 slots for free, which you have to unlock by leveling up. However, they only give you 3 free loadouts, and each loadout allows you to use only 2 weapons at a time. Vanity items to customize your character typically costs between 2000 spacebux to 8000 spacebux for a singular item, such as shirts, pants, accessories, hats, masks, etc.

The uglyGiven the steep prices of the cash shop, the lack of content updates, and the dwindling population, I cannot in good faith recommend this game. I honestly feel that if the game were updated more frequely, or the cash shop prices were to come down, that Loadout would have a fighting chance. But, personally, this game does little to encourage me to keep coming back to it. Loadout is great for a short term fix, or when you aren't in the mood to play any of your usual games. But simply put, there are other games that I would much rather commit to, both short term and long term.

reviewText:
The company that made this game is ridiculous.
According to the privacy policy, they can spy on your computer while you're in game, they can check the websites you visited before and after visiting the Loadout's official site... This is ridiculous.

Even though I did not accept the privacy policy after reading it (I usually don't even look at the privacy policy, my friend warned me), I was still getting e-mails! They send enough e-mails about the new updates, changes etc. to make your whole inbox get filled with spam.

Now, about the actual game:

CUSTOMIZING WEAPONS - this option looks very cool, but does not work good. Half of the parts that can be modified make the gun worse than the default one, and the other half is too overpowered. I don't get what's the point of modifying weapons, when some guy with a default rocket kills you shooting only twice?

Art - Graphics and models are the only thing that kept me playing this game for a while. The three characters that are in-game (you can buy them with REAL money) are well designed and each of them looks very different.

Sound - the weapon sounds, voices and all the other audio stuff are just not well made. I get the feeling that they did not put much effort into it.

Gameplay - Gameplay can be a little fun, but only with friends. Otherwise, it gets boring in less than 3 hours and the community in this game is scandalous - everybody is raging and abusing each other.

Verdict: I do not recommend this game. Apart from ridiculous privacy policy, the gameplay is boring and repetitive.

Its been a loooong time.

Last review for loadout, all I really said was how much fun I was having.
Things have changed.

There are now two versions of the game. The first, and original, hasnt been touched by the devs in ages. They left it behind. Personaly, this version was better. Upgrades were ease to get a grasp of, combat wasnt confusing, pvp was enjoyable. All they had to do was add a campaign mode and it woulda been perfect.

Instead....

Version two. The PvE story we wanted was put in here instead. All your work you had done on your main account, was now lost and you had to start from scratch. No money refunded, no in game items, nothing. Upgrades where changed into these weird card things that you can fuse other bits into to make them better. But that ment finding strongboxes filled with good loot that you have to PAY to get open. Yea, real cash. No more earning it for free. Pay to win!

After that virtual slap to the face, you now have to deal with the insane difficulty jump in the campain. COmbat became confusing with how difficult it became. You where now expected to have this amazing gear... that you need to pay to get from the loot safes. As a direct result, only the payers get great items, thus making their pvp game that much better.

After asking about a transfer of all the things I earned and bought (Way to much money, im ashamed to admit) I was blatently told, No

reviewText:
This is an excellent skill based third person shooter. The mechanics are awesome, the act of simply running and jumping with your character feels great then comes the games niche: the weaponcrafting. While there are many combinations not all of them are viable, however there are enough to cater to all styles of play. There are a wide variety of defensive weapons, aggressive weapons, long range weapons, close range weapons; whatever you find fun you can focus your weapons and loadouts around.

The devs work closely with the community and I highly recommend becoming part of the closed beta, there is room for competitive play in the future and hopefully a great amount of success. If you're bored of the current military based fps' then it's definitely worth checking out the game.

Here is a link to my Loadout montage playlist, check out the videos and decide for yourself if the game looks worth the time/money investment:
http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL53l70ESgmaFnt-P8kNbsAcZX_ItWRqRm&feature=mh_lolz

reviewText:
This game is absolute madness. The setting is unoriginal and generic, the characters cartoonish and ugly, and the gameplay over-the-top and messed up beyond belief. Combine that all together, and you get a love you either can't stand, or love beyond belief. And I went with the latter.

Loadout is fun. That's all it really is, fun. There's no stress you might get from other FPS/TPS games like CoD or Borderlands, mostly because of the fact you can't take this game seriously. The creators did everything they can to deliver a game that'll make you lose or die with a smile on your face, without feeling the frustration from similar games. Of course, this doesn't apply to everyone, but you get the general point here.

The weapon customization is awesome. Instead of choosing stock guns from different categories, you can design it in any way you want, from snipers to mini-guns to healing rocket launchers and whatnot. Even though some combinations might be considered OP"

reviewText:
I was going through my reviews and found this old one. I decided to change it.

I'm Chaos Epoch, one of the beta testers for this old gem. And one of the only people to have a wide branching concept of weapon ballance. The only other who came close was TaerKast. There were many others who knew a lot, but were never seen experimenting like i did, for more then an hour or so every week. Loadout was a game that was always so close to having it, but always stumbled.

When PS4 support was announced, the game was dead, after a long, crippled run. Management killed this game, took it's life away from the people who made it. Many bad calls were made. Lets build our own engine on a small budget for an experimental game. Lets not have actual numbers in the code for our weapon stats. Lets do a co op mode for the 4 russian people asking for it while the game suffers from blatent PvP issues. List goes on

Good game. Very good game. But it's dead Jim.

Loadout is a hellava game. The concept of it is pure gold. Make your own weapons. Make your own guy.

The modes are really fun. I would like to see someone else pull this game off. It's completly possible.

reviewText:
Was fun for a while, but the PC version has been all but abandoned by the developers. Situations like the one this game has found itself in are the reason people despise consoles, though their anger is usually misdirected onto the people who play console games instead of the developers like Edge of Reality who abandon their core players (the PC gamers who made them successful to begin with) for the relatively easy profit of console development.

PS4 version is leaps and bounds ahead of the PC one at this point. No updates, no communication, nothing that I've encountered, at any rate. Admittedly I've not been following the game too closely, merely casually observing, so perhaps things aren't quite as bleak as they seem. I have a feeling they are though.

If you absolutely must check this game out, play the PS4 version. Even then, I'd not give Edge of Reality any of my hard-earned money. I don't support companies who screw over one player base for another. They'd do well to look at companies like Digital Extremes (Warframe) and CDProjekt (Witcher 1-3) to learn how to support a game on multiple platforms.

Not recommended, even for free.

reviewText:
9/10

Absolutely an amazing game.

So um you're telling me that I can run around with a dangling pixelated p*nis? SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!
You're telling me I can see bo*bs? SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!
More than 44 billion gun customizations? Take my money already!
Its not P2W for all those are thinking that, all gun parts are purchasable with ONLY currency that can be earned by PLAYING MATCHES.

The only real world money currency neccesity is to look fabulous :D aka P2LF (Pay 2 Look Fabulous <3)

There are 4 different casual gamemodes and 1 competetive gamemode of the games we know in other FPS games mashed up with fun and a plot twist, for example,

Jackhammer(Casual) : Capture the flag with a gigantic shockwave raining hammer that the enemy team can take and use on opponants.
Blitz(Casual) : Control Point Capture with a small radius for maximum explosive damage. (Raise the boxers!)
Death snatch(Casual) : Basically Kill confirmed but you have to collect small bottles of 'Blutonium' that the enemy drop when they get killed.
Extraction(Casual) : This gamemode features a player on either team having to collect blue crystals of Blutonium and dropping them into the extractor. Both teams can kill the enemy collector for a new collector to be selected from their respective teams.

Annihilation (Competetive) : This gamemode features all the gamemodes (except Extraction) Mashed up into one single game mode, both teams try to reach a score of 10,000 so that the Enemy team's base's Shields will be dropped down. After that, the opposing team must take the enemy hammer, charge it at THEIR OWN base, bring it to the Enemy base and use the Charged Hammer on the Enemy base's power core creating a Massive nuclear explosion, ending the game with the victors.

There are so many taunts from doing an 80's dance, to Shuffling, to Micheal Jackson's Smooth Criminal, To twerking for all 3 characters.

Even though there are a few hackers and bugs, the Devs are working tirelessly in banning them and fixing bugs, the game also has a very active CM (@arctyc) who always helps everyone whenever possible.

So, all in all, this game SHOULD be played. Its very fun and amazing to play with friends with communication.

reviewText:
Loadout is a third person shooter that differs from other third person shooters I have tried. It is gory, fast, action packed, and has a large range of customization. Loadout can be found on Steam and takes a player’s Steam ID to add friends to the in-game friends list. My first impressions were that it was going to be a typical shooter. Nothing unique or worth mentioning about it, just some brief hype, however it turned out to be much better than that. At the home screen, a player can also see when there is happy hour and any changes that they make to their character will also be shown on the home screen, which includes weapons and outfits like this angry man you see here…

Graphics & Gameplay
The graphics work very well with the gameplay. The gameplay often involves trying to capture points and/or demolishing opposing players. This usually requires some large amounts of firepower. The graphic style becomes very brutal at certain times because during a fight, players will often get certain limbs blown off. The pseudo-realistic graphics make it humorous and gross at the same time. Sometimes, players will even run around with no heads. The gameplay is almost similar to other third person shooters; the main thing that makes it different is the customization available in weapons which allows players to see many different combinations. As players die they will drop their weapon allowing other players on either team to pick up the dropped weapon. This adds a bit to gameplay because of the large variety of weapons.

Game Modes
There are currently two types of game modes available. The first mode is a team death match mode where players will try and demolish each other. As players die, they will drop certain items that other players can pick up. If a player on the same team picks up this item, it will deny a kill, but if a player on the opposite team picks up the item, they will get a kill instead. The other mode is a dominion-type mode where the teams need to capture, defend, and attack points. These points will decide the final verdict of a winner. As the points are being captured, players will fight one another to try and stop the capture from the opposing team. I preferred the death matches over the base captures, mainly because I prefer to mindlessly kill during while playing these types of games.

Weaponcrafting
Weaponcrafting is Loadout’s strongest point. Players can use parts to craft and customize guns earned from playing matches. This is their weapon customization which appeals to a lot of players. It offers a large variety of customization and every aspect can be earned in-game. Players can choose from lasers to machine guns and they can also add effects to them such as fire or mine detonation. All the stats are displayed on the screen, which also display the stats that will change when switching certain properties on a gun. My person favorite thing to do was using a cluster rocket launcher with a fire effect on it. With this system in place, players were basically encouraged to make very bizarre weapons. Since players dropped their weapons as they died, it provided a chance for other players to pick up those weapons and see the different combinations that are possible.

Character Customization
The customization of a default character is non-existent. Players can choose to customize their characters in the outfitter. The outfitter provides a large selection of outfits, but most of them need to be bought. There are a few things that can be changed without a cost, but those small changes. Although it costs quite a bit, most players could probably buy all they want without having to worry much as long as they stay active. The customization is pretty vast if that’s the case. I think it’s important to have it accessible for most players and with this system, it’s mostly fair.

Currency
Spacebux are obtainable after every round through roulette and it can also be bought with real money. This may mislead people into thinking it gives an extreme advantage to some players, but it does not. The main reason comes from another form of currency which is for weapon upgrades. Upgrade points are another form of points a player must collect to upgrade their weapons to the next tier. Certain pieces need different amounts of upgrade points. This limits the gun advantage so most of the purchases for spacebux would probably go towards the customization of a character. Who wouldn’t want to make their character look snazzy?

Overview

Graphics – 4/5 – The graphics are smooth and match the settings of the world really well.

Gameplay – 3.5/5 – The gameplay is semi-generic but the guns make it much more interesting.

Customization – 4/5 – Customization is the strongest point of Loadout Given outfits mainly need to be obtained with spacebux, it’s still completely possible to fully customize your own character.

Community – 3/5 – Players aren’t as hateful as other games seeing as Loadout is a much less serious game than other shooters, but since action is always going, conversations don’t really get started.

Features – 3/5 – There aren’t many features other than the customizations and the fact players can jump high. Nothing really stands out in terms of special features.

Overall – 3.5/5 – Overall, the game is great. I really enjoyed it and I personally think it’s worth a try if a person is willing.

reviewText:
Tremendous game.

The weapon system may be a bit daunting at first, but allows for a exceptional amount of freedom, letting you build a gun that suits your playstyle like a glove. Combined with fast paced combat, Loadout's got an old-school feel that will appeal to fans of the Quake and Unreal Tournament franchises. It's also just a great looking game.

Built on EoR's in-house engine, it lets the dev team produce content at an extraordinary rate. The art team spits out beautiful cosmetics like no other, the complex balancing system is handled with admirable speed, and major updates occur with surprising frequency. EoR's done a great job managing and refining the game so far, and I look forward to its future.

Last but not least, the community is great. I'm definitely biased (I'm a forum morderator - ComradBlack, feel free to reach out to me), but the Loadout community has proven itself to be a fantastic and supportive place, where new folks are always welcome. Not only that, but the devs have proven to be exceptionally active; the community manager and several designers post on the forums regularly, and the CEO of the company is one of the most active members (Hi Rob). They also have informative live streams every week.

It's a fantastic and professionally executed game, backed by the most talented and caring devs I've seen in along time.

reviewText:
Back in the 90s, shooters were all the rage. They were fast and furious, with none of the slower, sneaky, stealthy, cover-based gameplay of today’s modern shooters. The days of Quake and Unreal Tournament were glorious times – but sadly, there have been very few fast-paced shooters of any real quality recently.

But one developer – called Edge of Reality – has been beavering away on a new shooter called Loadout which aims to bring back some of the twitchy shooter gameplay of the good old days. I’ll admit that this game completely slipped under my radar until a few weeks ago, and the fact that it’s free-to-play didn’t exactly get me too enthused. There’s bound to be some caveat; there always is with F2P, right?

Loadout is purely multiplayer: there’s no campaign and no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about. It’s a good old shooter that’s played over multiple game modes that we’re all familiar with, but with a twist to their names and objectives. Blitz (control points), Death Snatch (grab points dropped by killed opponents), Extraction (gather Blutonium) and Jackhammer (CTF) are all available on the game’s four maps that released when it launched.

Loadout
Lots of leaping around is required
Oddly enough, Edge of Reality decided that Loadout would work best as a third-person shooter. When the gameplay is fast you want to see everything around you and not necessarily your own back, so I thought the view in Loadout would be a real hindrance to my less-than-excellent FPS abilities. The good news is that third-person actually works really well and it’s something you don’t even notice after playing for a while. But why third-person?

The only reason I can think of as to why this is not a first-person shooter is the game’s art style. Edge of Reality have created a game that shares visual similarities with Team Fortress 2, focusing on being cartoony and over-the-top. There are currently three (excellent drawn and animated) characters to choose from: the Sly Stallone look-alike Axl, the Mr. T-inspired T-Bone, and the rather hideous Helga. There’s been a lot of care and attention put into these characters and that’s important when you’re playing a game that uses customisation as a selling point.

Loadout
We go all Disco because it makes you a better shot. OK, that’s a lie.
But it’s not just the characters. Loadout‘s big selling point, apart from being free-to-play, is that you can heavily customise your weapons. There are four basic weapon types: the laser-like Beam, the explosive Launchers, the bullet-spewing Rifle, and the cannonball-launching Pulse. These are the base weapons players build upon to make new and interesting tools of destruction.

As there are no classes in Loadout the weapons play an integral part in how you build your characters. For example: you can be a healer by creating a Beam weapon that fires healing rays, or you could become a sniper by equipping a powerful scope on one of the base weapons. The way you customise your weapons is down to you. That’s why the game is called Loadout. Genius.

Each player can create their new weapons, give them a unique name and then create a loadout (there it is again) from their array of created weapons to take with them into matches. These loadouts are selected at the start of a match but can also be switched mid-game when you die. There’s huge scope for experimentation, and it’s trial-and-error as to whether you can actually kill stuff with your creation. What looks like a good weapon on paper could be utter crap, depending on your skill level.

Loadout
Our first attempt at weapons.
Not all the weapon enhancements are available at the beginning of the game, as most need to be unlocked by playing and levelling up your profile. The more you play, the more you’re rewarded with the game’s main currency – Blutes – which can be spent to unlock new enhancements. There’s no pay-to-win rubbish on weapon enhancements, but there is a tech tree which has to be opened up to access new weapon features. This unlocking system is a problem when you want to try a new weapon feature but you can’t because it’s further up the tree. You’ll need to keep playing to earn more Blutes and possibly spend them in areas you may not necessarily want to, just to reach your goal.

The game’s other currency is SpaceBux, and this is where real cash comes into play. The main use for this currency is character customisation such as new outfits or emotes. You can ignore this completely and just play the game, but if you want to stand out then the quickest way is to drop some cash. The problem is that it’s not cheap, which is a real shame because the items that are available look great.

As an example, £13.99 will give you 16000 SpaceBux. A helmet costs around 1499 SB, a toothpick is 999 SB and a pair of Assless pants is 8999 SB. For your £13.99 you may get one really cool outfit but not much else. If you want to look the business in-game, then you’re paying top dollar for it.

Perhaps a rethink on some of the pricing would be a good idea, as everyone would enjoy seeing more visually appealing characters playing, and not loads of players using the three standard characters and outfits. That said, anyone who sticks with Loadout will probably think it’s money well spent.

SpaceBux can also be spent on an XP boost for periods of time to help unlock stuff on the tech tree quicker or to add extra loadout slots. If you really want to start messing about with the customisation then it’s quicker to do it that way, but again, it costs more. Damn you F2P!

Character customisation and emotes in action


Loadout is new and it’s got potential but it’s too early to say whether it will be embraced by shooter fans due to the fact there are only four maps and everyone is still finding their feet. Having sunk quite a few hours into the game now (and failed miserably at topping the end-of-match leaderboards) I’ve found it pretty enjoyable for a quick fix each day.

Messing around with the weapons is fun but it can be time-consuming to find the right fit as not every addition is useful on all base weapons, and the fact you need to keep playing to unlock more weapon features up the tech tree could get tiresome. If you’re a shooter whizz then you’ll probably be racking up the kills so this won’t be an issue for you – you just need to stick at it.

Edge of Reality has created a tasty shooter with fantastic customisation but it’s going to be down to the individual as to whether they can stick with it for long enough to really make good use of the potential within. Free-to-play isn’t easy to get right and I’m not sure if Edge of Reality has completely nailed it. They have to make money somehow, but the items are overpriced and progression may be a little frustrating for less-than-stellar players who doesn’t want to part with cash. If, on the other hand, you don’t really give a toss about buying stuff, then this is still a shooter worth your time.

Monetisation aside, the game plays well, the maps are well designed, and the characters are great. The funny emotes will probably wear thin eventually and the death animations will become old hat, but with the addition of more content like maps and game modes, Loadout has a fighting chance to gather a following – even if it’s not doing anything super-original.

It’s a refreshing change to be playing a speedy shooter like the good old days, and with Loadout being free-to-play, it’s certainly worth a shot. Boom boom.

reviewText:
Honestly, Loadout is one of the best F2P games to be released on steam in a LONG time. Now, I know what you're thinking. The game is definitely P2W, right? No. Not in any way. You can buy these coins, but they don't give you a competitive edge in the game in any way. They simply buy cosmetics and XP boosts, thats it. You can't use them to buy gun parts, those you can ONLY buy with the in game currency.

Now, Loadout is a multiplayer arena shooter in the similar style of Quake and Unreal tournement. You battle different players, or bots, in different matches that typically last 10-15 minutes each. The combat is very enjoyable and satisfying, mainly because of its chaotic nature. One moment you can think you have the advantage on a player, then they pull out their rocket launcher and shoot your face off. Literally. Or their teamates can bombard you with lazer beams. reviewText:
Solid combat and a blast when the teams are somewhat even. The level up mechanic makes the game really boring otherwise though. Watching a guy who can take your entire clip to the face turn around and one shot you with his higher level weaponry doesn't really give a good starting point for new players.

If you're willing to stick around past that though you might get to mess around with the really interesting and varied weapon design. In my brief time with the game I came up with tons of cool weapon concepts that I'd love to be able to put into practice. I however don't have the patience to sit through a game for that many hours just to try a new stock or barrel on a gun. If you do, this game might be worth your time.

As far as free to play games go this one isn't too bad. Most things that affect gameplay are tied to the in-game currency, which is always welcome. Every single cosmetic item however is for real world money. If you want to look unique, you're going to be spending some cash.

In summary, this game isn't my cup of tea, but I can see the appeal. If they ever implement some form of matchmaking so I'm against other new players instead of people with days of game time logged I'll probably be back. Until then, I can't really recommend this.

reviewText:
Game is very fun, easy to catch onto, has fluent gameplay, and the micro-transactions were BEAUTIFULLY done.

You literally don't have to pay a dime for the game to have all the fun, the only money you can spend on the game is for cosmetics/taunts that don't actually effect the core mechanics at all. -Again, very well done by devs.

Grinding xp is kinda slow to get to level 10 for matchmaking against other players, but fighting bots with other people DOES have a good turnout for teaching you about not over-extending, pushing attacks, defending objectives, and so on for the different game modes.

The wacky cartoon art style was very fitting for this game.

The game is fast paced, intense, and lots of fun.

The customization mechanics are easy to understand, and grinding for individual unlocks seems balanced (not too long but not too easy)

My only complaint is that the Pyro ammunition type is REALLY overpowered with afterburn damage.
-I guess this is kinda-sorta balanced as it does cost A LOT of blutonium (in game moneys you get from finishing games)

It's a game done right; there's really no other way to put it.

reviewText:
Loadout was a game that started with a fair bit of potential. As you can see, I've played a fair bit of it.

But I cannot recommend the game in its current form. As other reviewers have pointed out, the developers have abandoned the PC version in favour of the PS4 version. It went from being an arena shooter to being a grindy borefest which forces you to do missions you couldn't care less about in order to get weapon parts. What I liked about the game was ease of access to weapon parts and being able to just jump into a server to play for a bit. Of course, that obviously wasn't making enough money, so they set up a gear treadmill and fundamentally ♥♥♥♥ed over the Arena Shooter aspect of it for grinding.

As much as I enjoyed this game for a while, I can't forgive what they've done with it. It's not worth your time, or your money, to support these lazy ♥♥♥♥s. They had their chance to make something awesome, but then they blew it.

reviewText:
Oh, god, how I miss this game. I really do. There were those times when I'd had a bad day, or just needed to unwind, and cranking up Loadout was the key to quenching that desire to annihilate things. It's actually a kickass game, what with all the weapon combinations and the fast-paced play style, but... I just can't think of Loadout in the same way anymore.

I left the game for others in about October, and this March I decided to give it another go, and for some strange reason, I couldn't find a game. Well, the reason? This game has been abandoned. This glorious, beautiful, crude-humored game has been abandoned. Those days where I would join a local server and join the mayhem are long gone. Now I have to join UK servers with 400 ping just to get a match.

Where did the atmosphere go, Edge of Reality? On general principles I tend not to judge, but it's hard not to see the developers abandoning the PC version for the PS4 edition as a betrayal of the fanbase. What now? Does some indie developer come along and make a cut-rate version of this that nobody plays? Sorry Loadout, your time has passed.

reviewText: Fun free to play shooter. Not a pay to win, only thing you have to use real money for is character clothing, which you can get in daily prizes. Cuztomize your gun until it fits you best, with tons of customizable attachments and more. The game just got out of Beta, so the game is a bit buggy, some reason being, disconecting from servers for no reason and low ping issues. Getting into a match can take a while, a lot of people leaving lobbies, and people not readying will make you wait in lobby for roughly 3 minutes. Theres 3 characters to choose from (more comming soon probably) there is no difference for which one you pick which is kind of dissapointing. matches are very unbalanced, you can get in matches with level 20's when your level 1. The game is very fast pased and when your in a gun fight, your not going to go in cover rather your going to run around going guns blazing and jumping around. My biggest issue with this game though is that the game is so boring when you play with out a friend, if I dont have a friend with me to play, I will play one match to get my daily prize and I will stop playing, the reason being that the game is boring is that the game has very little variety, and when you have a friend, you will have someone to laugh with and have a good time with. The whole idea of the game is to customize and win, the wepon customization is probably one of the best wepon customizations I have ever seen, it isnt like Call of duty were you can put a cammo and a silencer and a red dot, instead you can shoose the wepon barell, the scope, what kind of bullets, stock, and much more customizable stuff. I would not recomend this game if you dont have a friend to play with. And let me say that any computer can run this game, my friends windows XP can run this game at 28 FPS. If you ever get bored with a friend  and looking for something to do, this game will be the perfect choice. Only good when you have a friend to play with.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Oh man, did I love this game. I had so much fun just messing around with random weapons and getting crazy kills.
I'm really sad the EoR devs abandoned the PC version for the PS4 version, after sticking with it for so long. I wanted to see what this game could become, it had so much potential. Now it's just a jackhammer camping simulator.

Pros: Good fun if you can find 7 friends to play with or something, you can create your own cool and silly weapons, and I like the animations and artstyle.
Cons: Dead community (good luck getting into a regular PvP game), no more updates, not necessarily pay2play but pay2pimp, and boring matches (mostly jackhammer camping).

TL;DR Abandoned gem

reviewText: Loadout is a fast, over-the-top, highly customizable shooter without the focus on classes and teamwork. It performs admirably thanks to strong map design, and a generous free-to-play setup that charges mostly for cosmetics. But the matchmaking system is straight-up broken, leading to frequent frustrating mismatches, and its small count of maps aren’t enough to keep me around for long. And now the climax of the whole review - the game is dead.

reviewText:
This game is absolute madness. The setting is unoriginal and generic, the characters cartoonish and ugly, and the gameplay over-the-top and messed up beyond belief. Combine that all together, and you get a love you either can't stand, or love beyond belief. And I went with the latter.

Loadout is fun. That's all it really is, fun. There's no stress you might get from other FPS/TPS games like CoD or Borderlands, mostly because of the fact you can't take this game seriously. The creators did everything they can to deliver a game that'll make you lose or die with a smile on your face, without feeling the frustration from similar games. Of course, this doesn't apply to everyone, but you get the general point here.

The weapon customization is awesome. Instead of choosing stock guns from different categories, you can design it in any way you want, from snipers to mini-guns to healing rocket launchers and whatnot. Even though some combinations might be considered OP"

reviewText:
Decent controls on a decent third-person shooter. Maybe a bit scant on deeper game modes, and the inclusion of a free-for-all deathmatch seems like just a skill-tester to keep idiots out of the real team-based objective modes.

The weapon crafting is fun. I haven't been able to dig into it since after the limited access beta, so it's infuriating to see so many weapon properties locked out right now, but when you have everything available, it's incredibly fun to use strange and exotic weaponry, and picking up and trying out other people's weapons is always a blast. Weapon crafting in games always hooks me, and this is no different.

The art style is fine, but the humor leaves quite a bit to be desired. balls. asses. Laughing yet? It's really puerile, and not so great as a result, but the game stands without it, so I hope they don't continue to bear down and focus on the lame parts of the setting/theme.

I'm recommend you try it, but just because of the current structure of the unlocks and the hamfisted crude humor, I'm slightly reticent to give it an unwavering Yes.""

reviewText: A very outrageous experience to be had, Although I do wish this was released sooner. Right off the bat I didn't enjoy the fact that I had to purchase customizable items for my character with real money but it's nice to see that it's not the only way to acquire cutomizable items and weapon customization is strictly with in game points you get after every match. Their are two different types of gameplay, one is for a more general and fun experience to be had with not much of a competitive feel to it while the other is more for competition. This is what I like mainly because it attracts both Casual and Hardcore audiences. Hopefully a trading system can be implemented later for character items (with some kickass background music during matches maybe?) All and all, It's crazy fun and I can't wait to force my friends to play this game when the full release comes out! ^^

reviewText:
This game is absolute madness. The setting is unoriginal and generic, the characters cartoonish and ugly, and the gameplay over-the-top and messed up beyond belief. Combine that all together, and you get a love you either can't stand, or love beyond belief. And I went with the latter.

Loadout is fun. That's all it really is, fun. There's no stress you might get from other FPS/TPS games like CoD or Borderlands, mostly because of the fact you can't take this game seriously. The creators did everything they can to deliver a game that'll make you lose or die with a smile on your face, without feeling the frustration from similar games. Of course, this doesn't apply to everyone, but you get the general point here.

The weapon customization is awesome. Instead of choosing stock guns from different categories, you can design it in any way you want, from snipers to mini-guns to healing rocket launchers and whatnot. Even though some combinations might be considered OP"

reviewText: Edge of Reality started with a simple, brilliant idea. What if an arena shooter let you fit together your own guns before every battle? What if those guns could shoot lightning, release flames, or even heal teammates? What if this shotgun had a scope on it? What would a fully automatic sniper rifle look like? These are the questions that can be answered in Loadout, their new free-to-play third-person deathmatch game. Unlike many free-to-play titles hoping to jump onto one bandwagon or another, Loadout has a style and presentation all its own. Even so, its not entirely immune to the pitfalls of the free-to-play genre, and that may put off some players that otherwise would have latched on to its off the wall gameplay.\n\nRead the full review over at Geekenstein.com: http://www.geekenstein.com/loadout-review/

reviewText:
Loadout is a soon to be (as of writing this) F2P third person shooter with over the top humor, zany effects and addicting gameplay reminiscent of old school shooters in the days of Quake and Unreal Tournament. You can buy the early access pack now and that gives you a few beta-exclusive clothes and a handful of ingame and cash currency. It features a robust and in-depth weapon customization system as well as an impressive amount of wearables for your character. As of now, you can only buy cosmetic items with cash points starting as low as 99cents for a few hundred points. You can upgrade and customize your weapon using ingame currency you earn from playing matches. As for the game itself, its fast paced and over the top, shooting homing missiles, laser beams, or plasma blasts you dispose of your opponents in a variety of different ways while rushing to complete a match particular objective. Gameplay can be hectic and overwhelming for those not used to this kind of game, but the style and fun of it makes it well worth giving it a shot. On the outside it might look like another toonish style shooter but it definitely isnt for your 7-year old kid, its got enough blood and balls (yes balls) to warrant a warning.

PROS
> Fantastic presentation & humor
> Tight & addicting gameplay
> Bots for party or offline play
> Brilliant weapon & character customization


CONS
> Eventually going to be F2P
> Over the top style might not be for everyone
> There may be weapon balance issues
> Sometimes Matchmaking falls short
> Cosmetic items are cash only
> Helga

All in all, its a very fun fast paced game that proves classic style shooters arent dead yet and can still make a comeback if done right, hopefully the benefits of paying for early-access is worth it instead of waiting.

Editors note: My friend derpy gifted this game to me, thanks derpy!

reviewText: It has finally been revealed, the phantom that has stalked your every wetdream, haunted your secret late-night thunderbating, and lingered in the back of every lewd thought you've had about your hair dresser, has come to light for all to see. Yes friends, Loadout has at long last arrived, and with it your prayers for a mature, sophisticated, quadruple A shootbanger have been answered. Gaze my friends, gaze upon the flawlessly executed character design that is so rife with jiggle bones and over-the-top personality (sprinkled with a sizeable dosage of pop culture references) that you've already ordered body pillows for every character before you've even played the game. But that's not all my friends, oh no that's only the tip of the phallus. Let your eyes linger on the DEEP weaponcrafting of Loadroute, for it is truly an eyegasmic experience for the whole family to enjoy. Stare in bewilderment, let your jaw slacken and your jowls quiver with succulent anticipation as you piece together your very own instrument of Hasbro approved destruction. Upon it's completion you receive a standing ovation from everyone you've ever loved as you christen your newfound love with whatever combination of ♥♥♥♥ and balls suits your deluded fancy, and then, OOHhhhHH THHEEENN, the REAL games start. Then it turns into an enjoyably casual twitch shooter version of TF2 without any of the stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or forced character personality, and it even has the capacity to be my favorite if I could stop having so many BadDragon marketers forcibly testing their newest products on me every time I try to shootbang.

CONS:

This game is definitely worth the closed beta fee

reviewText:
Loadout is a fast-paced F2P 3PS where you design your own weapons / loadout.  $IRL only buys cosmetics so you can't pay-to-win.  Unlock new weapon mods in your tech tree and level them up, etc  Great fun!

Gametypes in both PvP and PvBots (co-op) are:

* Blitz (random KOTH cap point)
* Death Snatch (DM with those killed dropping crystals that need to be collected to confirm kill)
* Domination (3 x set KOTH points simultaneously)
* Jackhammer (CTF with flag" being a melee weapon you can kill with to multiply the cap value)
* Extraction (1 member of each team is randomly selected as the collecter who picks up crystals and drops them in set collection points
date: while team defends him or attacks other team's collecter)\n\nEquipment you can unlock includes grenades (explosive
voteText: but limited like their cloak is)

reviewText:
What is Loadout? First and foremost it is an awesome game that can best be described as a 3rd person arena shooter/platformer. The combat is heavily movement based so expect to be jumping, rolling, and sprinting both in and out of combat. This game is fairly fast paced, so expect Times to kill around 1-3 seconds. Weaponcrafting is this game's heart and soul though. You can pretty much create any gun you want if you are willing to take some creative  liberties with it! Examples: railgun? Check! Volcano sniper ala Borderlands? Check! And a million billion other combinations? CHECK!
This is a great game that currentley uses the F2P business model (buy cosmetics and other stuff with real money) However the prices are fair and there are a ♥♥♥♥ ton of ♥♥♥♥ing sweet cosmetics. To be honest you can custimize your charecter more than your guns, which is pretty extensive on both ends.
Also the developers for this game are awesome, totally on point, and real down to earth. Im not a super important player, however on many occasions through weekly live streams, the Dev's hopping in to our Raidcall, in-game and on the forums I have been able to address them with my personal (yet hopefully valid) issues and always get a good response!

Buy in and experience the ♥♥♥♥♥iness that is LOADOUT

reviewText: I sort-of liked Loadout, with the ability to play with people I know, and doing Splat & Blam killing.\nThat was before the developers essentially gave up on fixing its AI errors to focus only on the long-awaited Beta-version. The Bot glitches and cheating is getting increasingly worse and blatant, We can't duel, like they promised. Weapon advancement is stalled in some locations, with the Bots able to do increasingly one-shot-kill damage and impossibly-aimed shots. I've seen too many Bots do suicide leaps off of bridges or cliffs, only to pop-up in a completely different location, and I've seen Bots hide under the graphics to avoid shots ... sometimes crossing the game-map while hidden inside the scenery" or shooting through "solid" structures to hit us.\nI made many of these comments to the developers
date: yet have had nothing from them to fix these very basic problems.\nAs it is
recommended: I don't think I'll even go for the Beta."

reviewText:
Let's all stand together and think.

What makes a shooting game fun? Is it the way you kill people? Is it the way you run? Is it the way your ♥♥♥♥♥ flops around whenever you are teabagging a nearby enemy? Well, if you like any or all of the above, you will love this game!

It mixes what retro shooters were made to be: Fast Paced and insane fun mixed with hilarity of destroying your enemy with the most ridiculous items imaginiable.

The community is amazing, the developers are not afraid to admit problems or even ask the community for help and even requesting something in-game can be placed there the next day!

The weaponcrafting is insane! Have you ever wanted to make a weapon that shoots fireballs that explode into mini fireballs that explode into smaller fireballs inside fireballs? No? What about just a plain old rifle that shoots out GREASE LIGHTNIN'?! You can do this and much more!

This is not just a plain old boring Third Person Shooter with small customization. This is Loadout.

Now you tell us... What's Your Loadout?

reviewText:
Ladies and Gentlemen, it's finally here!

Loadout has always had the mindset of a Free To Play game since the beginning, I was around in the early stages of Closed Beta when those maps you all will love were all grey and bland. I can say that I love the game, the gore, the action and the fast paced battles. I know that recently lots of free to play games have been receiving alot of flak for their business models but I can positively say that Loadout doesn't suffer from those problems because unless, like me, your looking for some beautiful vanity items then everything has to be earned with Blutes. Blutes are used to upgrade your arsenal but the only way to obtain these beautys it to play, play and play some more.

Oh yeah, I twerked with a half naked fat woman, you should too!

reviewText: Pure Chaos. This game brings back the true Multiplayer Arena Shooter genre, games like Unreal Tournament and Quake. reviewText:
Customization - 10/10
Gameplay Enjoyment - 10/10
Rewards System/Leveling - Not good yet

Loadout is made to have fun, and it's damn good at it. From level 1, the game abandons you to discover weapons on your own.This works because Loadout is not pay-to-win at all. Even the most expensive and customized weapons are arguably weaker than the stock rifle that you begin with.

This game has a great future ahead of it!

reviewText:
It's not a bad idea, but it suffers from the same problem all multiplayer-only games suffer: The game is as fun as the people you play with. Being that is not a very popular yet, the servers are mostly empty and usually imbalanced. This would be a lot more fun with a bunch of friends to play with.

There's two types of currency, one to buy cosmetic items ( only can purchase with real money ) and the other one to buy upgrades ( Blutes: can get in game through playing ). However, you can also buy experience and Blutes drop multipliers if you pay real cash, which gives an unfair advantage to those paying money. ( You do still have to play the game to earn the experience, you just get it a lot faster that if you didn't pay )

All in all is not a bad game for a lan party, for its price tag....

reviewText:
'A looney tunes cartoon directed by Tarantino' A brilliant summary of this game in my opinion.

This game is the breath of fresh air needed in modern gaming. Just when you thought arena shooters were long dead this game grabs you by the balls and screams at you.
Free to Play but that doesn't mean Pay to Win, the only things you might want to consider paying for are Extra Loadout and Gun slots aswell as some cosmetic stuff to make your character stand out from others.

The weapons are diverse and fully customisable (Though you cant colour your weapons to my knowledge hopefully they add that in.) The game is fun, easy to pickup and my god is it satisfying to obliterate somebody with your own gun that you created.

My only criticism is that the cosmetic stuff for your character is a little pricey and I would like to see a 'item drop' system similar to TF2 or CS:GO. Oh and Achievements (please add achievements i need my fix)

I have seen people criticise this game for its lengthy matchmaking times but c'mon guys it literally JUST went F2P today ofcourse they are going to hit server traffic they have adressed this on Twitter and Facebook and they are working on fixing it now.

Also this is one of the few games I can think of where I have shot somebody's ♥♥♥♥ off... So y'know it has THAT going for it.

reviewText: This game is.... awesome. It invokes the old school feeling of games like Quake and unreal tournament, while keeping it's own art style and hilarious brutality. While it doesn't break much new ground, the weapon crafting (even in this early stage.) adds a lot of depth (and death) ti what normally would be a kind of shallow game. The characters seem to be either references and stereotypes of DA MANLIEST MEN or complete freaks (such as Helga), which gives more to the comical feel. and speaking of comical, the deaths of your enemies (and yourself) will leave you laughing, chuckling and boisterously cursing at your foes. The deaths range from the unsettling throwing a tantrum while your skin is burned off" to " missing your upper torso while your legs run around like a headless chicken." to my favorite " a brief pause before silently flipping off your opponent." This game is certainly worth your time and possibly your money if you want to support the developers (and look good while doing it.)"

To get the full idea of this game, think about Team Fortress 2, mixed with Borderlands, with no pay-to-win.

The gameplay is pretty simple to learn, and very few times will someone be horribly overpowered to the point of making your playtime a miserable hell. It runs well, there's no classes, and it's very lenient for players, new and old.

The graphics are a great achievement; very good-looking, and easy to run. The gore is perfect eye candy.

While there ARE some possible in-game purchases, they're usually geared toward non-game-changing factors (i.e. Character's appearance). This effectively eliminates basically EVERYTHING WRONG WITH ALL FREE-TO-PLAY GAMES EVER.

The point I'm getting across here is basically this: Good graphics, simple gameplay, a metric ♥♥♥♥♥on of blood and guts per match, and it's not a pay-to-win game like almost every other free to play" game in Steam's library. It's good fun

reviewText: This game has been an absolute blast, within the first 24 hours of playing I have logged 15 hours! It is absolutely addicting, it was worth paying for the early access. The weapon customization is endless! So many combinations to work with! Great community as well, very friendly and welcoming. It will be released Free to Play once it's actually released, and it has a ingame currency which you earn by playing or using your wallet it's up to you. There is no Pay to Win or Pay for Power in this game which is a great thing as well. I recommend it to anyone that loves FPS games and a weapon system similar to Borderlands!

reviewText:
Manliest game ever.

And the people who cry around saying that rockets are OP are not manly, because I'm destroying rocket mid-air without even noticing it (I know that I'm doing that because you get bonus points for it).

And the people that say that there's no balance, that's because their weapons suck. It is not easy to make a good gun, but that doesn't mean that there's not balance. The more rockets you have in the same magazine, the less damage they do, for example. You can try your new weapons on a nice shot gallery before you buy the components, which is great.

reviewText:
Agreat title with a Great set of developers behind it. At the moment its still in the process of finding itself amongst the many hundreds of titles out there that offer the same thing, however the polish and subtlety's to combat are what make this Beta title one to watch.

You have a HUGE variety of customisation available straight from the get go here, with supportive developers and a nice community. The gameplays fast and frantic and at times can seem somewhat imbalanced, however if you settle down and fine tune your picks you'll realise that with each unique weapon there are unique drawbacks that need to be capitalised upon.

your team need a healer...not a problem hop into WEAPONCRAFTING and hit up the pulse healing or even rocket healing. If you are into customisation and in need of a fast paced shooter. Get down to loadout.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. First, i will start with the Pros

PROS

- Fast paced (extremely) game. YOu stand still, you're dead.

- INSANE weapon customization. Do you want a laser guided, flaming, timed cluster rocket that creates mines when it misses? You can do that. Want a minigun that shoots healing? You can do that.

- Make the characters your own with the customization system*
*Sadly uses a real money only system, but if you want to pay money, go ahead!

-The only classes are the ones you create. YOu have two weapon slots, and those could hold anything, YOu could have a healing rocket-launcher with a tesla beam.

I'm not going to say it has only pros.

CONS

- At the moment of writing, it has friend server problems. It sometimes shuts down, and leaves you to not talk with your friends. The party system works during that down time, but it's a little more complicated.

- There is NO other way to customize your character, except for promotions. I get it that you want some prenium only stuff, but ALL of it prenium only? That's too much. Also, you can't but ANYTHING to customize your character with for just 1 dollar. You may think So

reviewText:
This is an arena shooter in true form. Very fast paced, extremely high action and very skill oriented. The devs take care of the community, keeps them informed and if something is broke patches come quick.

Play-to-win or Pay-to-win? From someone who literally works in the free to play industry and have played and worked on a lot of them I can tell you this game is 100% PLAY-to-win. The only thing you can buy for money is cosmetics and grind boosts. Period. Play the game and see for yourself.

The balance on the weapons is great as you often have to balance utility and damage. The more useful it gets the less damage it will generally do. Shoot tons of cluster rounds and damage everyone, or skill shot that single shot rocket to just flatten a person out.

Unreal + TF2 + Killbill + rock n' roll = Loadout

reviewText:
I suppose for those who are simply scrolling by, here is your answer: This game is not Pay2Win

I REPEAT, THE ONLY ITEMS YOU CAN PURCHASE WITH REAL WORLD CURRENCY ARE TAUNTS, COSMETICS, AVATARS, AND BOOSTER PACKS.

Now that I have gotten the obvious question out of the way, I would like to justify my claims. I've played numerous F2P games, seeing such tragedies like Battlefield Heroes, to games that became F2P, like TF2. I like to believe that I have an eye for Pay2Win games when I see them.

PROBLEMS AT THE MOMENT:
Matchmaking. This is the obvious one, so much so that people are giving bad reviews based on that alone. Rightfully so, but I will say that there was no way that the Devs could have seen this coming. Back in 2013, there was even a day where the Devs tested the load on the servers, our very own Crash the Servers" day. This called to action a brave 2K (at the max) players to crash the servers
recommended: and we battled veterans went home with a free t-shirt for it.\nSo take the "stress test group"
voteText: and you now have the amount of players that are all trying to get on at the moment. It is a real shame
helpfulPercent: especially since the impatient ones bombed the 24 hour Dev stream
votesHelpful: but I can understand their anger. We are getting a cosmetic item for it though. This part of my review shouldn't be here for much longer

reviewText:
Loadout is one of those games that takes a familiar concept and adds a few twists and turns into the mix. For the most part yes it's an over the shoulder third person shooter, yes it's been done but no, there are NO set weapons.

Loadout actually does what's intended with allowing customisation to not only your character, but your guns as well, mix matching parts and pieces to make something special for you. A few examples of the guns I've made are:

- A minigun that shoots out steel spiked balls rather than bullets
- A rocket launcher that shoots grenades that split into smaller grenades that heals whoever they hit rather than explode
- A lazer that takes about 30 seconds to fire one shot, then uses all of it's ammo
- A gun that shoots bouncing bullets that eventually return to you and kill you
- A minigun sniper rifle that's actually really useless.

The list goes on to designs I've not even considered yet. Point is you'll be at this for a considerable amount of time before you actually get to the playing. After building a gun, you can test out whatever you've made on some bots to see if they're effective, useless or cause you to accidentally kill yourself upon using it once.

While it is currently Early Access, bugs are bound to happen and issues will occur but the responce times of Edge of Reality's team quickly fixing whatever might crop up and still have time to add more content is amazing in itself so hopefully, the issues that might occur will not last long at all.

All in all, it's a great deal of fun and laughs, even when the gun backfires and you blow yourself to bits.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Such a hilarious fun game.  From what I've seen on the casual portion of match making there are 4 game modes: CTF, Control Point, Kill Confirmed (From Call of Duty) and this Extraction Mode.  Personally KC and Control Point will be the most fun game modes because it's just constant action.  CTF will be a great competitive mode that I think people will enjoy playing.

There are a ton of weapon customizations from the projectiles you shoot to how fast you shoot them and even different weapon types to fit your needs.  You can have fire rockets, pulse beam sniper, there's just a lot of variation that hits different play styles.

Character Cosmetics are hilarious, this game is quite mature so if you're a young person I'd disable the nude option.  Because you can actually have a nude character, butt naked.  That's how extreme and bizarre the cosmetics are in this game, lot of stuff to purchase comestically.

With this being a F2P game everyone wants to know is ti pay to win?  Not really, there's pay to early a little more xp and in game currency, similar to league of legends, but not really pay to win.  More pay to get ahead faster which if it's a turn off for you that's fine I get it.  It's not as bad as I thought though.

Now there are a lot of things you buy with points such as unlocking different grenades from the tech tree as well as other equipment etc... then there's unlocking attachments for your weapons which can help you figure out the style of play you want to pull off.  Right now I'm not good enough to say if you pay for the xp boosts that you'll get so far ahead because you still have to grind out the games like everyone it's not like those F2P fps games where you pay money and boom you have a weapon.  That's silly and this way is much smarter it rewards people for playing the game, and game modes.

It's going to be free to play so play it, it's great fun.  You don't have to spend money unless you want to make your character look hilarious.  Other than that, play it try it out and find out for yourself.  Unless you're like me who keeps jumping around FPS games because nothing that has been out has been good enough. ;)

I'd rate this game 8.5/10.  Visually looks great, UI is polished and well done, doesn't about a minute to find a game, tons of ways to customize my weapon/character for my playstyle and the way i want it to look.  There are some minor issues I've had like you need to use -DX11.0 in console to launch the game in fullscreen windowed mode as well as things like removing the ability to join on your friends at any given time.  They might change or fix that sooner or later, but overall the game's enjoyable and relaxing.  I don't give it a 10 because I feel like they could tweak a thing here and there like maybe some in game stuff which indicates what's going on for new players and what not, minor stuff.  Maps for CTF are too big things like that.  More personaly things that others might not agree with.  It's in that 8-9/10 range of fun especially for a game that's going to be free.  Haven't played something this polished in a long time.

reviewText: I have had TONS of fun with this game. When I first saw it, I figured it had potential but I had no idea what I was in for. This game has provided me and my friend endless hours of laughter and enjoyment. The humor is dead on (ha, literally), the violence is gleefully brutal and yet still manages to crack me up, the guns are hilariously destructive, the list keeps going. If you enjoy any kind of action/shooter multiplayer games, and you have a sense of humor, this game is definitely for you. Plus it's going to be free to play in a about a week! What more could you want? And since some people will ask: no, it is definitely NOT pay-to-win. Money gets you cosmetic items only. You can buy blute boosters (blutes being the currency) if you feel like you're getting them too slowly but the game is such a blast that I honestly don't mind playing a few extra rounds to buy an attatchment I want.\n\nWhat are you waiting for? Get this game!
