reviewText: Wow...!This ♥♥♥♥ is awesome
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Reasons its awesome:

(perspective from co-op vs bot player)

The EOR LOADOUT GAME ENGINE is really Refined and Smooth. The PHYSICS are EXCELLENT and u get a real feel for the game after awhile.  It doesn't make me tired or dizzy after playing awhile like the VALVE engine and others and the Cartoony graphics are a fun pretty enviroment to play in.
The Audio is EXCELLENT and intuitive and the game play is a razer fast twitch play to a laid back and remote kill game so it covers a lot in a sandbox.
The latency is the best I have seen, and that generally averages 30-35ms.
So between the GAME ENGINE and LATENCY it Really Feels CUTTING Edge!
A lot of work has been done to balance the guns ahead of release and the more you dig in the RPG nature of Weaponcrafting and strategy of use, the more you enjoy.
The AI of the bots level up as you level and it is difficult to corral them unless all 4 team players are on the same page.
The Game rewards team work and assist as its more important to do collective damage than to be a RAMBO KILL Monger. Good team work really owns the day.

I have only seen vids/streams of the people vs people mode, but it would seem the same would carry over.

This really is a free to play game and not a PAY to WIN approach like so many others.
The only thing you purchase is cosmetics and the ability to double XP/blutes and a few slots.
The only advantage of double XP is that it cuts down the time in half to level up parts and guns, but you need experience to use each gun part per personal taste.

There are a few bugs like connection issues once in awhile and the matchmaking system isn't fully worked out.

There is also needed effort to improve the Player VS Bot experience such as being able to change the difficulty of the bots per your mood or team experience rather than it being automaticly done for you.
There is also a need to have a Vote to Kick feature to prevent TROLLING  and a Private Party or friends only" game.
Features prevailant in almost all co-op vs bots online games. Campaign mode in Left4dead being the perfect example of perfectly honed CO-OP  VS BOTS.

The sense of humor of the game is ICONIC
date:
It still makes me smile to taunt/dance at the end of each round.


In short "Crude Rude and Lewd but ever so Refined"
"

reviewText:
This is an arena shooter in true form. Very fast paced, extremely high action and very skill oriented. The devs take care of the community, keeps them informed and if something is broke patches come quick.

Play-to-win or Pay-to-win? From someone who literally works in the free to play industry and have played and worked on a lot of them I can tell you this game is 100% PLAY-to-win. The only thing you can buy for money is cosmetics and grind boosts. Period. Play the game and see for yourself.

The balance on the weapons is great as you often have to balance utility and damage. The more useful it gets the less damage it will generally do. Shoot tons of cluster rounds and damage everyone, or skill shot that single shot rocket to just flatten a person out.

Unreal + TF2 + Killbill + rock n' roll = Loadout

reviewText:
Pros:
*Runs well while still looking good
*Game modes are typical of a shooter (Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, etc), but each has their own little twist to it to make it fun and fresh.
*Community seems nice.
*Weapon crafting is just as good as it sounds, and thankfully the upgrades can be purchased with the ingame points, not the virtual currency.

Cons:
*At the moment, matchmaking is a nightmare as the servers are getting overloaded.
*The cosmetic items are much better than the ones in TF2, but they all require you to pay lots of virtual cash for it, which is fine on its own, but I wish just some of them could just be unlocked or bought with points, not cash.


Overall, this is a pretty fun game, maybe not as great as TF2, but if you like TF2, classics like Quake or Unreal Tournament, or Borderlands, you'll probably have a lot of fun in this game. Just expect to drop a lot of cash for cosmetics and be prepared for extremely long matchmaking.

reviewText:
Really, this game is a top-notch free-to-play.  I'd rank it right up there with the likes of Team Fortress 2.

The weapons crafting system is where the game really shines.  You earn XP through playing games, and spend the XP buying new parts to build weapons with.  I think there are currently something like 6,000,000,000,000 (yes, Six Billion) possible weapon designs available.

The artwork is great for what it is, and the effects are just brilliant.  From bouncing, flaming, or electrical bolts flying everywhere to actually seeing the bullet holes and damage in your character, they really paid attention to detail.

The game modes are great renditions of the classic capture-the-flag and team deathmatch modes that you find in most team shooters.  I found the Ranked Annihilation mode to be awesomely fun - you earn points and choose which buffs to buy your character when you can afford them, between 3 possible choices.  This mode imparticular gives it a moba-ish feel that I really enjoy.

You're missing out if you do not give this game a try, that's the bottom line.  It's free, but I'd easily be willing to pay 20-25$ if they wanted to charge that for it.  It's certainly that good.  I'll probably be buying the 20$ Steam Starter pack for it soon, too.  Those steampunk goggles look too cool!

TL;DR:  Great game.  10/10 for a Free-to-Play.

I definitely recommend Loadout to anyone looking for a fast paces shooter, I prefer FPS but I still very much enjoy the game - third-person works fine.

reviewText:
Loadout is probably the best Free 2 Play game on Steam, I would highly recommend trying it out.

It's a fast paced third person shooter with cartoonish environment and characters. It features highly customizable weapon choices, I mean.. you can customize a weapon in any way you want (such as fire, electricity, or even normal bullets etc. , beam weapon, rocket launchers, rifles, pulse weapons).


Best part: In no way is the game Pay 2 Win. There are two currencies in game: Blutes and Spacebux.

Blute is primaray currency used to buy weapon/gadet upgrades for your weapons. You get it by playing matches and on daily prizes.
Spacebux is obtain with real money BUT can only be used for buying cosmetics for your characters.
So anything gameplay/mechanics related cannot be just skipped to. All gameplay content(maps, game modes, weapons) is available to free 2 play player.

Level design is awesome, as well as the game modes. My personal favorite is Jackhammer. It's a creatively redesigned Capture the flag game mode, only where flag is a hammer, which you can actually use to slam other players while returning to base. Annihilation is also pretty nice (if im correct, this will be a part of competitive part of the game), its a combination of all game modes put on 1 map.

I saw quite a few people say The game is a TF2 clone". I don't really see how
date: the only thing they have in common are the cartoonish graphics.\n\nThe game had some problems on launch with friend lists and matchmaking constantly being down but the developers fixed it quite fast and even gave out free in game cosmetics as an apology. They're really taking a part of the community and listen to people. Keep it up
recommended: you guys are awesome!\n\nAs for the cosmetics
hoursPlayed: if you're down on spending a few bucks you'll be amazed at how many items and taunts are available to buy(most of them really hilarious).\n\nTo sum it all up: You're probably going to have tons of fun and laughs if you play this."

reviewText: Loadout is fast, fun, and crazy.  The variety of guns you can create is absurd, and the amount of work that's gone into making even randomly generated guns as balanced as possible is incredibly impressive.  The characters are expressive, very customizable, and really convey a fantastic 1980s-action-movie-by-way-of-Bugs-Bunny sort of attitude, which makes the entire game just flow perfectly.\n\nIt's just going to get better over time, and I think it's really worth checking out.

reviewText:
It's mayhem, it's guns, it's explosions.


Edit (31/8/15) :

This is a great game, both in concept and execution.
The idea of making your own gun from the gun type to gun element is interesting to say the least, and the third-person shooter mayhem that it is makes it a very fun game to boot, more so if you have friends playing with you.

From what used to be a possibly pay to win model, the developers have instead revamped the entire progression system, making desired weapon parts obtainable through playing more. Which is good.

What isn't good is that the developers have abandoned this game, and there's barely any servers and active players left. It's a 'ded gaem'. Stay away.

reviewText:
Meh.

After all the Reddit posts being a massive circle jerk, I have to get something off my chest. You may love this game, for its crude humor and 'random' gameplay. The way you may customise yourself for real money, sure, like TF2, but at least there is an economy. Everything is expensive, too expensive to bother with. My time is precious to me, and I dont want to waste it on the hopes of having fun that may never occur. Drone Drone Drone. I can go on (I wait, I do) Anyway, I probably dislike this game based on the amount of unconditional praise its recieving, or becuase my hatred has festered in my mind, but Alons y. Read on, random viewer.

Fine Fine. Ill expand. Im typing this as I think of it, so bear with me. A few niggles I have from a few hours of play are these. Firstly, there are very little maps/gamemodes, but it is a early game, so forgiven. Secondly, they sell themselves as a fully customisable game, but the customisations are not that great. For example, there are four weapon types, each with 5 ish bullet types. You can customise the barrel, which is good, but some are useless. You can customise the stock, which is also good, but all of them, for the rifle-ish guns anyway, are useless. You literally can buy an aluminium stock that makes you gun WORSE. Ammo cap isn't really needed, as the amount of ammo held is sufficient. You buy upgrades with money, wich comes in too slowly for you to easily find a gun style that fits you, as when you buy an upgrade it only applies to that weapon type, eg Fire shot on a pulse rifle is good, but you will need another 3k to buy a fire shot for the beam. Any customise character options are bought with real money, and untill you give the audience a reason to buy them, no one will. What else, What else, the controls are a bit finicky, but could be getting use to. The extraction gamemode is stupid, needs more challenge in it. The PvP is kinda difficult, as most players are use to fighting bots, with is more fun anyway (for me).
Enough negatives though

Loadout is free. Yay
Great aesthetics,I like them, though a little crude.
Gore and death is made always nice to see, so dying is fun. Yeah, I know, wierd

Hmmm, blah blah blah, make upgrades a bit easier to get, so you can form your own playstyle, as the skill tree makes upgrading said weapons your true goal. Yeah, a skill tree, in an online game. Expensive and stupid. You can buy and upgraded anything from mini turrets to heal grenades, but WHY BOTHER? Wierd, but you know...

Personally, It needs work, lots of it. But you can wear a pixelated ♥♥♥♥♥, so thats amazing, if you want to pay for it.

Concluding le rant, play this game. Try it, its free. My only wish is that it gets BETTER.
(Steam, make a 'Meh' recommend option pls)

reviewText:
With this game launching on the 31st I should write this down already in a sad attempt to give this game attention so I won't be playing a ded gaem alone because it isn't Dota 2 or an Autism Simulator that may or may not have zombies in it.

Loadout is a F2P Third Person Shooter with heavy emphasis on it's gun customization.

The customization itself is about as varied as they advertise it to be. I don't think it's billions" of combinations but millions might be a better estimate. I've made downright stupid and ineffective weapons and absolutely devastating and rediculous things that just shouldn't exist
date: but the balancing between weapons parts are pretty well done given the potential there was for overpowered weapons. Every part you change or add has strengths and weaknesses that favor different playstyles. I single barreled rocket launcher that just explodes is a good basic thing to start with if you just want to get into a fight with some reliable damage dealing
recommended: but an 8 barreled rocket launcher that can fire all 8 shots at once that stick to the ground as mine and explode in proximity to anyone who gets close to them into a shower of electric flak would be perfect for a capture point match where you need to force shield using players off the point quick and easy.\n\nThe game also has a very effective movement system that they should advertise as much as the guns
hoursPlayed: with a simple roll and jump you can work your way on top of nearly any structure in the game for a better vantage point
voteText: as well as make yourself a hard to kill target in modes like Death Snatch (kill confirmed) and Jack Hammer (CTF with a flag you can KILL PEOPLE WITH for more points)\n\nNow as I hear a lot of people complain about when a new F2P game comes out

Bots are kinda wonky with the auto aiming/failing to shoot at all and within the last few patches, they can basically jump in and out of pits while dodging without dying.\n\nLoadout can be fun and frantic, but it doesn't feel very deep despite the amount of weapons you can cobble together- some types are simply worlds better than others. It's full of immature crude humor so if that's your thing, try it out.

reviewText: For a F2P game ' Loadout ' is surprisingly well made. The first thing you'll note is the pace & how slick everything is with genuinely good humour.  The maps are a mixture of ' Team Fortress 2 ' & ' Brink ' which is no bad thing. Everything can be customised, so the more you play, the more you unlock. All game mode sessions will last around 10 mins, so expect frantic fragging at it's finest. Well worth giving it a go if you have a few moments to spare.

reviewText: Very fun game, a breath of fresh air from many other FPS shooters. The cartoony animation of the game combined with the creativity of maps, weapon design, purposefully over-the-top gore, and character cosmetics come together to create a fun and casual FPS to play with many other people. Creative variations of generic gamemodes such as Jackhammer (CTF) and many mini-control points instead of just three main ones provide a nice change from generic FPS game types.\n\nDefinitely recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a casual FPS they can experiment and have fun with, as well as play together with groups of friends. Have had some great times playing this game with my friends.

reviewText:
Harmless fun. A fast-paced third person shooter sort of in the same vein as TF2.....SORT OF.

The gameplay is just some fast paced mindless killing, kill the other team with 4 different types of guns and a huge amount of upgrades. The gun customisation is where this game excels. There is a lot of different parts to put onto the different types of guns you can have to suit your playstyle, whether you prefer to run in guns blazing with a mini-gun esque machine gun, or you prefer to stand further back and pick of enemies with a short burst rifle style laser gun....its all available with the expansive gun customisation!

I liked the humor in this game too, 3 different characters to choose from and like i said before its got that Team Fortress 2 style of humor and a similar art style. The game is free to play which is a plus and there is no pay to win additions to the game, all the gun upgrades are free!

However. There was a few things that the game couldve done better. The character customisation is where this game falls short. Don't get me wrong there is a good variety of clothing for characters but it is all really expensive. Now i know this is how the game has to make its money but even TF2 lets you unlock hats or character customisation pieces over time....this doesnt and it ends up with 8 guys all running about as the rambo esque guy. Plus everybody feels the same, again compare it to Team Fortress, all the characters in that game have depth and are all very different but in this its a skin slapped on the same character.

Overall for what Loadout is, it's not a bad game. It's fun, addictive and can kill a good few hours mowing down people with the assortment of weapons and pieces you can add to it. But these flaws kind of make the game fall short and really just make you wish you were playing TF2. 6/10

reviewText:
One of the best Non-Paywall, Non-Pay2Win F2P games, right up there with Team Fortress 2.
If that doesn't pick your interest, then I sure as hell dunno what will.

Word of advice when trespassing this cartoonified (and surprisingly innocent) gore of a Third-Person Shooter:
Expect a handful of weapon combinations to just not work efficiently in-game, from the most obviously dumb ones (Bolt Action Mag + X-Round Burst Triggers) to ones that look fairly balanced in paper but outright fall flat on their face the moment you try to make a stand (In short, anything with Bolt Action Mag, X-Round Burst or Spooling Triggers)

That said, if you liked the game as much as I did, then please use some of your money to support EoR (as they deserve it) with goodies that may or may not directly or indirectly affect your overall gameplay.


...What?
You won't really need those additional weapon slots, loadout slots and resource boosts.

I mean really now, the first weapon they give you has all the parts necessary to kick 90% of the casual player's buttniks, and heck, if used right, the first grenade you get can decimate a whole group by itself.
And really, if you REALLY need like 8 weapon slots and 4 loadout slots just to be good, then clearly you need to check your own weaponry first, and get rid of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Burst and Spool Triggers and Bolt Action Mags that are hindering your DPS and assault capabilities like an old lady asking for a charity runner to slowly cross an empty road in fear of a Ghost Train that you can easily Suplex for a 1-Hit KO anyway!

One word of advice; if it's your first game of loadout, play against other players. The bots use completed weapons regardless of levels so it's much easier (and fun!) to start off playing against people with the same experience and weapons as yourself at first.
Other than that, no real issues. Great game!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Loadout - Now this is how to Free-2-Play. In this brainchild of Team Fortress 2 with hints of Borderlands, two teams of four players each are pitted against each other in several different gamemodes.

The name of the game here is customisation, while you can only choose from three different playermodels, each one can be customised with a plethora of clothing-items and accessories to make him or her stand out. More noticably though are the options for customising your weapons. Apart from the very basic assault rifle you get given at the start, you can unlock dozens of new gun parts through playing the game and researching them down a tech tree. Pretty much any kind of weapons you can think of can somehow be recreated through weapon-crafting. The main inspiration here can be Team Fortress 2, as handheld rocket launchers or a healing beam-weapon can easily be made, but the options exceed this by far. Want to make a mortar that shoots flaming clusterbombs? Go ahead. A sniper rifle shooting electric beams? No problem, once you have the parts for it.
Very big props go out to the developers for not messing up their Free-2-Play model here, all of the things you need for weapon-crafting can not be purchased through microtransactions, they must be earned by actually playing the game. This game's premium currency is solely used for the cosmetic aspects. The only downside here is that, while you can earn clothing-items occasionally, they are very rare, so your character will end up looking fairly bland and generic until much later, unless you spend real money on it.

Now, with all the options for different weapons there are of course quite a few combinations that do not make sense or are just not viable on the battlefield. You can come up with some extremely situational boomsticks and still find yourself outmatched by a boring beam-sniper. It is completely up to you, however, so you can find the combination that best suits your personal playstyle.
The game is still not finished, so some features are not yet implemented. This means that for those who love variety, not much is offered after playing a few rounds and testing out some of the guns. The game seems to lose its novelty-value fairly quickly right now. But hey, it's completely free to play, full of humour and the microtransactions, as of now, will not allow anyone to get unfair advantages over those who won't pay. Definitely worth at least a look.

reviewText:
(9.5) Loadout is amazing, around two days in and have a good amount of hours. Starting with the wide array of customizations, especially with guns(which none of them will need real currency). Using Blutes, which are research points for guns and Spacebux, which are wardrobe and purely aesthetic. The gameplay is phenomenal, with a challenging community and a few maps and gamemodes. Even bots are challenging! The guns are organized and balanced. There is that comic relief and uniqueness to this third-person shooter. However, a couple of minor bugs does de-rank this game, other than that it's a superb game that's gameplay is flawless.

[Note: I am not judging the launch day malfunction with servers, because of how quickly they managed to get playtime in]

Final Conclusion: It is a raw, vulgar, and gorey game that includes great customization and solid gameplay

reviewText: Loadout is an interesting free to play third person shooter with a crude sense of humor. The game boasts weapon customization as its selling point. As you play and level up you unlock new gun parts, very much in the vein of Blacklight: Retribution and customize your base weapon. The game play feels somewhere between TF2 and COD with a hint of old arena shooters. Animations are fluid and game play is smooth although a bit limited feeling as you run forward, shoot, and dodge. Death animations are probably the most interesting part of this game for me. Being able to control my legs running around after my upper body has been blown off is pretty entertaining. Definitely an interesting new shooter. Not great but it's free and entertaining so check it out.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I've had many a poor experience with F2P shooters, mostly because a lot of them allow you to buy your way to the top.  In Loadout, the only things real-world money can do is purchase avatar outfits and icons, and increase your experience by 2x for a limited time.  Everything else must be earned by playing the game. In other words, you'll advance faster simply by being good at the game, not because you have a fat wallet.

That said, I've been having a surprisingly good time playing Loadout.  Gameplay is fast and fluid; combine this with the art style and the game reminds me somewhat of Team Fortress 2.  The violence is over-the-top, to the point where dying and watching others die is actually refreshing and funny at times.

After about three hours of playing, I've donated $10 to the devs (yes, I purchased outfits for my dude) because this game made me laugh and is fun to play - I have yet to get annoyed by any gameplay mechanics or ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off that I was royally pwned by someone who paid their way to the top (again, that's not possible here).  I'm shocked I'm saying this, but I can recommend this F2P shooter!

reviewText: This game is a breath of fresh air to an over-saturated marketbase.  I looked at the steam page and read up on the game and thought to myself, sure..  every game says they are completely customizable and offer a ton of unique options to make your character truly unique...but then you get in the game and there's always one or two combinations that beat anything you could possible choose to make yourself unique
date: so it isn't even worth it."  But this game does the customization right
hoursPlayed: while "billions" of possibilities is quite a stretch(at least as it currently stands)
voteText: it does offer quite a bit.  I haven't seen the same one gun on any character yet - at least not that I've noticed.  They allow you to custom-choose each piece that makes up the gun
helpfulPercent: such as the stock
votesHelpful: ammo
votesTotal: how the ammo projects through the air
votesFunny: the element of the ammo
column16: the scope
column17: the size/efficiency of the magazine...pretty much anything you'd want.  The best part about it is that literally any combination will work together!\n\nI also enjoy their spiced-up versions of classic shooter game modes
column18: such as capture the flag and standard deathmatch.  In deathmatch
column19: the objective is the kill your opponent AND collect the vial of "blutonium" that their character drops.  The important part is to actually get to the vial of blutonium and pick it up before one of the opposing team players does(this is called a "denial").  If you aren't able to pick it up
column20: you just missed a chance to score the core points of the game for your team(the twist is that killing doesn't rack the points up - the vial collection does).\n\nIn capture the flag
column21: the flag is actually a big ♥♥♥ hammer that can kill opposing players in 1 big hit.  The catch is that the hammer only has 5 charges to perform hits during your run with it
column22: but if you manage to kill opposing players during your run back
column23: the hammer takes that number of kills and respectively ups the score your team receives when you manage to bring the hammer back to your base.  I think adding that one little aspect(the flag is actually a weapon in-and-of itself) is a neat little twist to an old fan favorite.\n\nAll-in-all
column24: this game is definitely worth a buy for any shooting game fanatic.  If you're on the edge
column25: all I have to say is:  it's a minimum of $10 - get it!  These devs obviously know what they're doing
column26: and they need your help in this early access stage to get the word out and release more content!  If you're happy with the game

reviewText:
i can't say i've got a ton of time in the game.  i've put in enough to get a decent loadout for myself, and learn the flow of the game a bit.

that being said, i feel pretty confident saying this really is some of the most fun i've had with a shooter since before everyone got better at tf2 than me lol

it really is a great game with incredible flexiblity in progress.  even in my first few games, i didn't feel particularly outmatched (i was with a good team)...

if you're just looking to try a different kind of shooter, this is the game.  who knows, you might even replace some of your favorite triple a titles with this one.

you know that disappointment that often follows spending money on a game?  it's not here.

reviewText:
Timeraider's Review Time:
Loadout
3d third-person non-serious shooter

Gamplay: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10
Performance: 8.5/10
Problems/bugs/glitches: 9/10
Storyline: -/10
Emotional attachment/ general immersion: 8/10

General score: 8.5/10

Additional comments:

This game is a hidden jewel. After the very succesfull Team Fortress 2, alot of companies tried to repeat that succes by making clones... none succeeded. This game however has the potential to trow TF2 in the garbagebin.
It has very fitting graphics, a few different gamemodes, a nice amount of maps, alot of cosmetic stuff and a third-person view instead of first-person. One thing i cannot express in text or show you in a video is fun .. the game is just fun to play and every second is enjoyable. Also a big feature of the game.. weaponcustomisation. You can actually make your own guns from a massive pool of parts and chassis ..  and even paint/customise the appearance of the gun (within a few patches).
Did i also mention it will be f2p when in open beta and when released? .. well.. it will be f2p!

reviewText:
Most reviews simply gush about it being fun or quirky but really don't address the guts of the system. LEts change that shall we?

First off, graphics wise. To put it bluntly it's a beautiful game. The maps render beautifully, the character models are somewhat interesting, the guns diverse in appearance. In the first case the maps are all really well done, from brush work to textures, light levels to paths it all looks rather stunning when you arrive the first time. Definitely gotta give props to whoever did the art for this game. The character models are like what you see in the vids, they're quirky, obscene and generally jiggle all over the place. With ten players all on screen blowing the hell out of each other I didn't notice any graphical slow downs with everything maxed. The guns, the biggest selling point, is where things tend to get a bit weak sauce. Yes in the customization screen they look hugely diverse but in gameplay you're never really going to notice anything other than the varied projectiles. So yeah 'customize' your gun to look however you want....nobody but you is really going to notice it.

Gameplay wise, it's simply chaotic fun. Between body parts being blown off to ingrained flip offs and crazy stage dives the CTF (or hammer in this case), team deathmatch and 'Bounty' game modes all fill their various niches. Capture the Hammer adds the most unique element in being able to smash opposing players to a pulp with your 'flag'. The one drawback however as I learned the hard way, you can only do this hammer kill 4 times before you are left unable to do anything. So why do it at all? Every kill you get with the hammer increases its worth so even if you're behind on scores, get four kills and then cap and you can well re-even the playing field.  The gun mechanics are again the biggest selling point but also the weak link. Like most FPS's, Loadout suffers from 'If it goes boom you win'. Bullets, energy, beams. All pale in the raw destructive force of explosive rockets. With a few upgrades I turned my already strong rocket launcher build into a one hit death gun. And I didn't even need to put the explosives on guidance or manual explosion to start dominating matches. In short: Rockets = win. They might reload slow but with the variety of movement controls you can easily dodge around while doing so to unleash explosive hell.

Now the tricky element: F2P. The model revolves around paying for cosmetics. There's no pay 2 win here....Unlike most f2p models its also not pay 4 advantage either. You might get an xp booster that lets you level a little faster but it doesn't affect gameplay. However if you want to customize your digital you to look as freaky or bad@$$ as possible...expect to pay. All the cosmetics are locked behind the real money currency and thus far I haven't seen an in game way of earning any amounts of it. The in game currency of Blutes are what you use to unlock your gun parts.  Sadly the pricing skew is somewhat...unique. For several guns expect to see upgrades cost your upwards of 4k+ blutes EACH. While others of the same tier cost less than 1k. And once unlocked to get the full juice out of them they have to be played with and levelled up.

In short is it a good game or a bad game?

To answer bluntly its not bad. If you like blowing things up its great mindless fun. The weapon part leveling system will likely get tedious fast and those that stick with it will undoubtedly have an advantage over those that join fresh in a few weeks. If you enjoy that then play this now. If you came for the vast customization shown in the videos expect to be disappointed unless you're ready to drop some money, between earning enough blutes to access the 'billions of weapon options' or dropping real cash to make the three models look more than default the initial experience is going to get repetative really quickly.

reviewText:
I have been playing the beta for a long time, its super fun. Check this game out. they add cool new stuff all the time, and really listen to player feedback.

This game isnt class based, but you can create guns that do healing people or guns that charge friendly targets up. You start by creating guns and then taking them in out in a few game modes including capture the hammer and what is essentially kill confirmed from call of duty.

The maps are not plentiful but the game modes do mix them up pretty well, there is a day and night variant of some of them

Between the full character customization and the creating guns from stock to barrel, this game is worth giving a try, best part about it is its free. FREE!!

p.s. making your own gun from scratch is badass!

This game isnt class based, but you can create guns that do healing people or guns that charge friendly targets up. You start by creating guns and then taking them in out in a few game modes including capture the hammer and what is essentially kill confirmed from call of duty.

The maps are not plentiful but the game modes do mix them up pretty well, there is a day and night variant of some of them

Between the full character customization and the creating guns from stock to barrel, this game is worth giving a try, best part about it is its free. FREE!!

p.s. making your own gun from scratch is badass!

reviewText: Load out is a good microtransaction game. You can not get an advantage by purchasing weapons. All weapons are earned by playing in matches. The costs to unlockand upgrade weapons is reasonable and forces a certain level of specialization. However,  you can test it before you unclock it to make sure you are getting what you want.\n\nThe one weakness this game does have is that while there are dozens of viable options for this game damage" done seems to be a critical stat. This is some what mittigated by certain game modes that require people to group up to cap flags and get points. However
date: the game is going to need some addtional content as right now it feels a little vanilla.\n\nYou can unlock new costumes for your charecter with real money
recommended: but right now the cost is too high and I don't see myself buying anything.\n\nOverall the game feels like variation of TF2 combat with a little bit of WTF was that?"

reviewText:
I don't quite find this an exciting game. Yes, it's fun, yes it has over-the-top wacky gore effects, ridiculous animations and what not, but most of the humor is crude.
At the core, this is still a fun team-based shooter for getting in and shooting people without overly concerning yourself with specifics.

The vaunted weapon customization doesn't quite strike me as being -exceptionally- creative. It's essentially a switch-your-6-parts-to-taste system, it's not like you can create the Particle Accelerator from Turok: Dinosaur Hunter with an underslung beam rifle.
Most of the attachments sound rather run of the mill, and I can't seem to find an option to recolor my weapons. But if you were satisfied with Dead Space 3's weapon crafting, you will likely be satisfied with Loadout's.
Of course, the game is still fresh out and the developers are clearly active, so maybe we'll be seeing the really crazy stuff eventually.

Graphically it follows Team Fortress' look and runs very well, but with the few servers available you might have trouble getting smooth gameplay. Especially because it seems like the game runs on a P2P netcode.

For a free game, yes, it's recommendable. It's just not special to me.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have to say, I love this game! The mechanics of customizing your gun by unlocking different parts, while offering interesting characters, fun maps, and an exciting, fresh playing-style is more than I could ask for in a game right now.

However, the economic aspect is poorly done, and turns me off a bit from the game entirely. In-game, there are two forms of currency, the one you earn by playing, and the one you purchase with real money. This, right here, is an outdated method of an in-game economy that makes me a little sad. Do you know why Korean MMO's make so much money? Do you know why Candy Crush makes so much money? Because you don't HAVE to spend money to unlock anything. It's there to buy if you want it, which is awesome! Loadout however, makes you spend money to take the happy-trail off of a character. Minuscule non-game-changing waste of a mechanic, right?

It is free-to-play, which is awesome, and I wouldn't mind supporting the game by paying money in the slightest. In fact, I desperately want to support this game. But I don't have $20 to spend on the starter pack, and I refuse to support an outdated, frustrating, and forced form of a digital economy. Please developers, do what's best for the players, and I promise they will flock even more openly to you.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
